docs.title: Contributing
docs.text:
Welcome! This section explains how to contribute to the wiki, how the folder structure works, and where to find examples and templates you can copy.

The goal is to make contributing easy, predictable, and low-risk — even if you’re new to MkDocs, Obsidian, or docs-as-code workflows.

docs.title: How this folder is structured
docs.text:
The Contributing/ folder is a self-contained guide that mirrors how the rest of the wiki is organized.

Contributing/
   ├─ index.md ← You are here (section overview)
   ├─ FAQ.md ← Common contributor questions
   ├─ Changelog.md ← Changes to contribution rules/templates
   ├─ Draft Notes.md ← (hidden from navigation)
   ├─ Getting Started/
   │  ├─ index.md ← Step-by-step guides & explanations
   │  └─ Example.md ← Concrete examples you can copy
   └─ .pages ← Navigation rules (infrastructure)

A few important notes:

  • Every navigable folder has an index.md that acts as a landing page
  • Subfolders represent logical sections, not just file storage
  • Some files may exist but be hidden from navigation
  • Navigation order is controlled locally via a .pages file

You don’t need to edit .pages unless you are changing navigation behavior.

docs.title: Adding a new page to this folder
docs.text:
1. Create a new Markdown file in Contributing/
  2. Give it a clear, descriptive name
  3. If it’s an important page:
  4. Add it explicitly to Contributing/.pages
  5. If it’s minor or supplemental:
  6. Let it be picked up automatically via ...

Example:

Contributing/Style Guide.md

docs.title: Adding a new subfolder (section)
docs.text:
When adding a new folder:

  1. Create the folder
  2. Add an index.md inside it (required)
  3. (Optional but recommended) Add a .pages file to control ordering
  4. Update the parent folder’s .pages if this is a major section

Example:

Contributing/New Section/
   ├─ index.md
   ├─ Examples.md
   └─ .pages

docs.title: How navigation works
docs.text:
Navigation is filesystem-driven, not centralized.

  • The sidebar is generated automatically from folders and files
  • Ordering, visibility, and titles are controlled by .pages files
  • Some content may exist only for reference and not appear in navigation

If something doesn’t show up in the sidebar: - Check the nearest .pages file - Look for hide: rules - Look for explicit nav: lists

docs.text:
Start here: Getting Started

That section contains: - Step-by-step examples - Sample folder layouts - Pages you can safely copy and adapt - Explanations of common patterns used across the wiki

If you’re unsure how to structure something, there’s probably an example there already.

docs.title: General contribution philosophy
docs.text:
• Navigation is curated — not everything needs to be in the sidebar
  • Search is automatic — content is discoverable even if hidden
  • Folders represent concepts, not just storage
  • Consistency beats cleverness

If you’re ever unsure, copy an existing pattern and adjust it slightly.

If something here is unclear, outdated, or missing — that’s a contribution opportunity in itself 🙂

docs.title: Gaps to Fill — Information to Collect
docs.text: Use this as a checklist. For each gap, collect the information listed; once you have it, we can update the wiki.

docs.title: 1. Security Rating (World/Maps/Security Rating.md)
docs.text:
What we need: Replace the placeholder numbers for each SR (1–9) with real in-game data.

For each Security Rating (SR1 through SR9), please collect:

Field Example (current placeholder) Your data NPC ship level range e.g. SR1: 1–10 Max NPC ships per sector e.g. SR1: 3 Recommended player level range e.g. 1–10 Recommended ship hull tier e.g. T1–T2 Any special notes e.g. “Starter-friendly”

Where to get it: In-game observation, dev/patch notes, or community notes. If exact numbers aren’t available, “best guess” ranges are fine — we’ll mark them as indicative.

docs.title: 2. Equip Points (Ships/Equip-Points.md)
docs.text:
What we need: Either (a) remove the “Full details coming soon” box, or (b) add real content so the box can be removed.

Please collect (if available):

Item Notes EP by ship class How many Equip Points each ship class (or size) has (e.g. Shuttle 10, Frigate 15, …). EP by ship tier/level Does EP change with ship level or tier? Defense unit EP How EP works for Planets, Garrisons, Outposts, Shipyards (base and per level if applicable). Item cost rules How item rank/rarity affects EP cost (e.g. “each rank adds X”).

Where to get it: In-game ship/unit inspect, in-game wiki, or HELP. If you can’t get full tables, a few examples (e.g. “Shuttle has X EP”, “Rank 5 weapon costs Y EP”) are enough to expand the page.

docs.title: 3. Technology (Gameplay/Technology.md)
docs.text:
What we need: Enough to replace “We'll add a categorized overview here” with real content.

Please collect (any that you can):

Item Notes Categories How techs are grouped in-game (e.g. Hull, Weapons, Movement, Crafting). List or export Full technology list from HELP → INFORMATION → TECHNOLOGY LIST, or a screenshot/export. Ranked vs non-ranked Which techs are “ranked” (don’t stack with lower ranks) vs “non-ranked” (stack). Examples are enough. Sources Which techs come from Artifacts vs corp research vs items vs ships (brief list or examples).

Where to get it: In-game HELP → Technology list; in-game wiki; or a text/CSV export if the game allows.

docs.title: 4. Skills (Gameplay/Skills.md)
docs.text:
What we need: Enough to replace “Full skill list and recommendations will be added here” with real content.

Please collect (any that you can):

Item Notes Skill list All (or main) captain/ship/corp skills and what they do (e.g. +XP%, Evasion, Hull). Max points per stat e.g. “Up to 10 points per stat, reduced benefit above 5.” New-player recommendations 3–5 “get these first” skills (e.g. +XP%, Evasion) and why. Where points come from Leveling, Artifacts, etc. (we already mention Artifacts; confirm or add).

Where to get it: In-game skill tree, in-game wiki, or community guides.

docs.title: 5. Weapons (Items/Weapons.md) — optional
docs.text:
What we need: Only if you want to go beyond the current overview.

Please collect (optional):

Item Notes Damage types e.g. Kinetic, Energy, etc., if the game shows them. Weapon tiers/ranks How weapon rank affects damage or EP cost. Examples A few weapon names and stats (e.g. “Plasma Cannon: Rank 3, 12 EP”).

Where to get it: In-game weapon stats, item inspect, or wiki.

docs.title: 6. Starmap (optional new page)
docs.text:
What we need: Only if you want a dedicated Starmap page (we already have World index + Maps).

Please collect (optional):

Item Notes System list Names of solar systems (or “50+ systems” and a few examples). How to open Starmap e.g. “Hamburger menu → Starmap”. What the map shows Faction colors, security, jump gates, etc. (we have some of this in Maps; any extra).

Where to get it: In-game Starmap UI and in-game wiki.

docs.title: 7. Player Guides (Getting Started/Player-Guides.md) — optional
docs.text:
What we need: Only if you want to remove the “Guides in progress” box and lock the list.

Item Notes Final list Which community guides to keep (with titles + URLs). Short description One line per guide (e.g. “New player basics”, “Gear and builds”).

docs.text: Gap Wiki page to update Security Rating data docs/World/Maps/Security Rating.md Equip Points details docs/Ships/Equip-Points.md Technology list/categories docs/Gameplay/Technology.md Skills list/recommendations docs/Gameplay/Skills.md Weapons damage/tiers (optional) docs/Items/Weapons.md Starmap (optional) New: docs/World/Starmap.md or expand docs/World/index.md Player guides list (optional) docs/Getting-Started/Player-Guides.md

docs.title: Priority order (suggested)
docs.text:
1. Security Rating — One table per SR; high impact for players.
  2. Equip Points — A few numbers or examples so we can drop “coming soon.”
  3. Technology — Categories + list (or export) so we can add an overview.
  4. Skills — List + new-player tips so we can add content.
  5. Weapons / Starmap / Player guides — Optional; collect if you have time.

When you have the data, you can paste it here (or in a comment) and we can turn it into wiki text and update the pages.

docs.title: 3. Interlinking Strategy
docs.text:
• Hubs: Each section’s index.md should list and link to all child topics (like Entities/Currencies and Entities/Structures already do).
  • Cross-section: When a page mentions another concept (e.g. Skulls, Ships, Corporations), add a Markdown link to the canonical page (relative within section, absolute across sections). See Markdown Links.md.
  • Breadcrumbs: Optional: end each page with a “See also” or “Related” list linking 3–5 related pages.
  • In Game WIKI links: When converting <u><link="X">Y</link></u>, map “X” to the target file in this plan (e.g. “Ships” → /Ships/index.md, “Tech Points” → /Entities/Currencies/Tech Points.md).
  • Fix broken links: Homepage currently links to Ships and Weapons; once Ships exists, fix to [Ships](Ships/index.md) (or relative from docs root). Add Weapons under docs/Items/Weapons.md or docs/Ships/Weapons.md when you have data.

docs.title: 4. Ordered Steps to Start Filling the Wiki
Phase 1 — Fix & Foundation (do first)
docs.text:
1. Create missing section stubs Add docs/Ships/index.md and docs/Items/index.md with short placeholder text so the homepage links work. Optionally add docs/Getting-Started/index.md and link it from the main nav (e.g. via docs/.pages).

  2. Fix homepage links In docs/index.md, change [Ships](Ships) and [Weapons](Weapons) to proper paths (e.g. [Ships](Ships/index.md), [Weapons](Items/Weapons.md) using relative paths from docs root or a stub).

  3. Update docs/.pages Add Ships, Items, and Getting-Started (and any new top-level sections) to docs/.pages in the order you want in the sidebar.

docs.title: Phase 2 — High-Value, High-Traffic Pages
docs.text:
1. Getting Started From In Game WIKI: How To Play, FAQ. Create Getting-Started/How-To-Play.md and Getting-Started/FAQ.md; interlink and link to deeper pages (Ships, Corporations, Maps).

  2. Ships overview Fill Ships/index.md from the “Ships” block: 10 classes, fleet size, captain levels, 50 variants, link to Ship Crafting, Elite Ranks, Ship Mods.

  3. Corporations & Alliances Expand Entities/Corporations/index.md; add Alliances (page or section). Link to Structures, Artifacts, Relics, Corporate Defenders.

  4. Currencies Ensure Credits, Skulls, Tech Points, Star Shards are complete (already present; enrich from In Game WIKI). Add Relics as a page under Entities or Resources.

docs.title: Phase 3 — Structures & World
docs.text:
1. Structures Expand Planets, Garrisons, Outposts, Shipyards (and Deployment, Jump Gates) from “Corporation Defense Structures” and related blocks. Add Artifacts if not under Structures.

  2. World / Maps Replace World/Maps/index.md placeholder. Expand Security Rating table; add Starmap and Factions (Wyrd, Het, Precursor, Pirates) from In Game WIKI.

docs.title: Phase 4 — Items & Combat
docs.text:
1. Items hub Fill Items/index.md (Item Types, Gear Score, drones). Add Stats (full list), Item Crafting, Pity Loot, Void Items, Mutate Item Kit, Diminishing Returns.

  2. PVP & Arena Expand Gameplay/Activities/Player vs Player (PVP)/index.md and Arena.md (rules, rewards, Skulls). Link to Skulls, Defense Structures, Maps.

  3. PVE & Invasions Expand Player vs Environment (PVE)/index.md and Invasions.md. Link to Missions, Events.

docs.title: Phase 5 — Abilities, Tech, Events
docs.text:
1. Abilities Create Gameplay/Abilities/ and pages for Grapple, Hack, Drain, Technician, Taunt, Deflector, Junker. Link to Stats (Hit Chance, Evasion, etc.) and Ships/Items where relevant.

  2. Technology Single page Gameplay/Technology.md (or Items/Technology.md) summarizing tech sources (Artifacts, corp, items, ships); link to HELP in-game list.

  3. Events Create Gameplay/Events/ and pages for Daily, Holiday, Free Gifts, Party Boxes, Reward Point Gifts. Link to Currencies and Missions.

docs.title: Phase 6 — Polish & Optional
docs.text:
1. Ship Mods, Elite Ranks, Hardcore Dedicated pages under Ships (or linked from Ships index). Interlink with Arena, Invasions, Oblivion.

  2. Oblivion Server Single page; link from Gameplay and World. List rule differences from primary server.

  3. About / Meta Spellbook, Delete Account, Review The Game, Player Guides (with external links). Optional Spaceball policy.

  4. Weapons When you have data (tiers, damage types), add Items/Weapons.md or Ships/Weapons.md and link from Items/Ships index.

  5. Consistency pass Every index.md lists its children; every cross-reference uses the correct relative/absolute link; “See also” where useful.

docs.title: 5. How to Use This Plan
docs.text:
• Per task: Pick a step (e.g. “Phase 2, step 5 — Ships overview”). Open In Game WIKI.md, find the matching [[[Topic]]], copy and adapt content into the target file, then add links to other wiki pages using the map above.
  • With AI: Share AI-Context-Guide.md + this file + (optionally) the relevant slice of In Game WIKI.md so the AI can draft or expand a page and suggest links.
  • Tracking: Check off steps or move them to a “Done” section as you go; add new topics to the map when the in-game wiki or community adds them.

This plan aligns with the current docs structure and In Game WIKI v1.5.0. Adjust paths if you rename folders or adopt a different hierarchy.

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text:
This guide walks you through the three most common contribution tasks step by step:

  1. Modifying text on an existing page
  2. Adding a new page
  3. Adding a new folder (section)

You do not need to understand the entire system to contribute safely.

docs.title: Modifying text on an existing page
docs.text: This is the easiest and safest way to contribute.

docs.title: Step 1: Find the page
docs.text:
• Use search in Obsidian, or
  • Navigate through folders in the file tree

Open the .md file you want to edit.

docs.title: Step 2: Edit the content
docs.text:
• Change text directly
  • Add or remove sections
  • Fix typos, clarify wording, or expand explanations

Use normal Markdown:

## Section heading

Some text here.

You may also use Markdown Links when linking to other pages:

[[Contributing/FAQ|Frequently Asked Questions]]
[[Contributing/index|Contributing]]

docs.title: Step 3: Save and preview
docs.text:
• Save the file
  • Preview in Obsidian if you want
  • Commit your change when ready

That's it. No navigation changes required.

docs.title: Adding a new page
docs.text: Add a new page when you're introducing new content within an existing section.

docs.title: Step 1: Choose the correct folder
docs.text:
Pick the folder that best matches the topic.

Example:

Gameplay/

If you're unsure, check for similar pages nearby and follow that pattern.

docs.title: Step 2: Create the file
docs.text:
Create a new Markdown file with a clear, descriptive name:

Gameplay/Status Effects.md

Avoid vague names like: - Notes.md - Stuff.md - New Page.md

docs.title: Step 3: Add basic structure
docs.text:
Start with a title and a short introduction:

# Status Effects

This page describes status effects that can be applied to entities in the game.

Add sections as needed.

docs.title: Step 4: Decide if it belongs in navigation
docs.text:
• Important page?
    • Add it explicitly to the folder's .pages file
  • Minor/supporting page?
    • Let it be included automatically via ...

If you don't know, default to automatic.

docs.title: Adding a new folder (section)
docs.text: Add a new folder when you're introducing a new conceptual area, not just a single page.

docs.title: Step 1: Create the folder
docs.text:
Example:

World/Factions/

docs.title: Step 2: Create an index page (required)
docs.text:
Every navigable folder must have an index.md.

World/Factions/index.md

Minimum recommended content:

# Factions

This section documents the major factions that exist in the game world.

The index.md acts as the landing page for the section.

docs.title: Step 3: (Recommended) Add a .pages file
docs.text:
Create:

World/Factions/.pages

Basic template:

nav:
  - index.md
  - ...

This ensures: - The section is clickable - The index page appears first - Future pages are included automatically

docs.title: Step 4: Add pages inside the folder
docs.text:
Example:

World/Factions/
├─ index.md
├─ The Syndicate.md
├─ Free Traders.md
└─ .pages

Use wikilinks between related pages where appropriate.

docs.title: How to know if you're doing it right
docs.text:
You're probably on the right track if:

  • You copied an existing pattern
  • Your folder has an index.md
  • You didn't fight the navigation system
  • Your change is easy to understand in isolation

Consistency matters more than perfection.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
For concrete examples you can copy, see:

[[Getting Started/Examples/index|Examples]]

If something here feels unclear or awkward, let us know!

docs.title: Markdown Links
docs.text: This guide explains how to link pages correctly in this wiki, with clear rules for when to use relative vs absolute links. Following these conventions keeps links predictable, portable, and compatible with both MkDocs and Obsidian.

docs.title: The Golden Rule
docs.text:
Links should point to source files, not rendered URLs.

Always link to the .md file path inside docs/, never to a slug like /hello-world.

docs.title: Link Types at a Glance
docs.text: Situation Use Example Same folder Relative page.md Child folder Relative Folder/index.md Parent folder Relative ../index.md Distant section Absolute /Section/Page.md Templates / global refs Absolute /Contributing/index.md

docs.title: When to use them
docs.text:
Use relative links when linking to pages that are:

  • In the same folder
  • In a child or parent folder
  • Part of the same section that might be moved together

docs.title: Why
docs.text:
• Mirror the file system
  • Survive navigation changes
  • Work in both MkDocs and Obsidian
  • Easy to reason about

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
Assume this file:

docs/World/hello.md

Same folder

[Maps](maps.md)

Child folder

[Planets](Planets/index.md)

Parent folder

[World overview](../index.md)

Sibling folder

[Ships](../Ships/index.md)

💡 Tip: If you could reach it with cd in a terminal, you can link to it relatively.

docs.title: When to use them
docs.text:
Use absolute links when:

  • Linking across distant sections
  • Referring to canonical pages (FAQ, Contributing, Index pages)
  • Writing templates or examples meant to be copied

docs.title: Format
docs.text:
Absolute links always start at the docs/ root:

/Section/Page.md

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
From a page in Contributing/Getting Started/, use relative paths to other sections:

[Contributing guide](../index.md)
[FAQ](../FAQ.md)
[Ship classes](../../Ships/index.md)

From the docs/ root, links are simply Section/Page.md (e.g. Ships/index.md, Entities/Currencies/index.md).

docs.title: Filenames or folders with spaces
docs.text: Use the literal space in the path so the link matches the file or folder name on disk (e.g. Tech Points.md, Jump Gates.md, Player vs Player (PVP)/Arena.md). Do not use %20 in internal links — that can break resolution in some builds.

docs.title: Don’t link to rendered URLs
docs.text:
/hello-world

Rendered slugs depend on titles and theme behavior and may change.

docs.title: Recommended Style Rules (Summary)
docs.text:
• Prefer relative links within a section
  • Use absolute links for site-wide references
  • Always link to the .md file, not a rendered URL
  • Do not rely on titles or slugs for navigation

docs.title: One-Sentence Mantra
docs.text: If you can trace the file path with your eyes, use a relative link. If you want a global reference, use an absolute one.

docs.title: External Links (Off‑Wiki References)
docs.text: Markdown links can also point to external websites (outside the wiki). While these are sometimes necessary, they should be used sparingly and intentionally.

docs.title: When External Links Are Appropriate
docs.text:
Use an external link when:

  • The information is authoritative and primary (e.g., official developer posts, patch notes, or APIs).
  • The content is too large or out of scope to reasonably mirror on the wiki.
  • The link provides verification, not opinion (e.g., source citations).

Example:

For official patch notes, see the [developer announcement](https://example.com/patch-notes).

docs.title: Why External Links Should Be Minimized
docs.text:
Excessive external linking can introduce problems:

  • Bias: Linking selectively to certain creators, forums, or communities can imply endorsement or favoritism.
  • Link rot: External pages can change, move, or disappear over time.
  • Fragmented knowledge: Readers are pushed off‑site instead of finding answers within the wiki.

As a rule:

If the information can live on the wiki, it should live on the wiki.

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
• Prefer internal pages over external links whenever possible.
  • If an external link is needed, ensure it is:
    • Neutral and factual
    • Clearly labeled (what the reader should expect)
    • Not required to understand the core content
  • Avoid linking to:
    • Opinion pieces
    • Monetized content (ads, referral links)
    • Single‑person interpretations when a neutral summary can be written instead

docs.title: Recommended Pattern
docs.text:
Write the content locally, then optionally add a source:

This mechanic was introduced in version 1.4 to rebalance fleet combat. 

*Source: [Official patch notes](https://example.com/patch-notes)*

This keeps the wiki self‑contained, neutral, and durable, while still allowing readers to verify information if they choose to.

docs.title: Using Markdown
docs.text: This page provides canonical examples for writing and formatting content on the The Infinite Black 2 Wiki. All contributors should follow these conventions to keep the wiki clean, consistent, and professional.

docs.title: Headings
docs.text:
Use headings to structure pages logically. Do not skip levels.

# Page Title (H1 – only one per page)

## Major Section (H2)

### Subsection (H3)

#### Minor Details (H4)

Rules - Each page must have exactly one H1 at the top. - Use sentence case for headings. - Avoid emojis in headings (allowed in body text if appropriate).

Paragraphs & Line Breaks

Write in clear, concise paragraphs.

This is a paragraph. It should explain a single idea clearly.

This is a new paragraph. Avoid walls of text.

Do not manually add line breaks inside paragraphs.

docs.title: Emphasis
docs.text:
*Italic*  
**Bold**  
***Bold Italic***

Guidelines - Use bold for important terms or first mentions. - Use italic sparingly (titles, emphasis, flavor).

docs.title: Unordered Lists
docs.text:
- Fast 
- Durable
- Expensive

docs.title: Ordered Lists
docs.text:
1. Warp to target 
2. Engage shields 
3. Deploy drones

docs.title: Nested Lists
docs.text:
- Weapons
  - Lasers
  - Missiles
- Defenses  
  - Shields  
  - Armor

docs.title: Links
docs.text:
We use standard markdown links, because the tech lead couldn't figure out how to configure wikilinks plugin with mkdocs properly. If you'd like to attempt it, contact the owners of this wiki.

See Markdown Links for examples of how to link pages.

docs.title: Naming Conventions (Pages)
docs.text: Consistency matters more than perfection.

docs.title: Page Titles
docs.text:
• Use Title Case
  • Be descriptive, not vague

Good - Carrier - Ship Classes - Harvest Drones - Faction: The Pirates

Avoid - car - Ships2 - Stuff - Guide_final_v3

docs.title: Inline Code
docs.text:
Use for commands, keys, or filenames.

Press `F` to interact. Edit the `mkdocs.yml` file.

docs.title: Code Blocks
docs.text:
site_name: The Infinite Black 2 Wiki 
theme:   
  name: material

docs.title: Admonitions (Info Boxes)
docs.text:
Material for MkDocs supports admonitions.

!!! info
    This ship excels at hit-and-run tactics.

!!! warning
    This information may change in future patches.

!!! danger
    Using multiple accounts may result in a ban.

docs.title: Collapsible Sections (Spoilers)
docs.text:
Use for spoilers or optional deep dives.

??? spoiler "Story Spoilers"
    The player captain is a mass-produced clone with no moral compass.

docs.title: Tone & Style
docs.text:
• Write in neutral, informative language
  • Avoid speculation unless clearly labeled
  • No first-person opinions (I think, In my experience)
  • Assume the reader is intelligent but new

Good

This weapon is commonly used in PvP engagements due to its high burst damage.

Avoid

I think this weapon is really good and I always use it.

docs.title: Final Notes
docs.text:
• When in doubt, copy an existing good page
  • Consistency beats cleverness
  • Ask before inventing new conventions

If something isn’t covered here, bring it up with the project lead.

docs.title: Entities
docs.text: Entities are the organizations, currencies, and structures that shape the world of The Infinite Black 2: corporations and their alliances, the currencies and resources you earn and spend, and the structures (planets, garrisons, outposts, shipyards) that corps deploy for territory and rewards.

docs.title: Sections
docs.text: Section Summary Corporations Join a corp for tech, ships, and protection. Alliances, Corporate Defenders, and how corps work. Currencies Credits, Skulls, Tech Points, Star Shards, and Relics — what they are and how to get them. Structures Defense units: Planets, Garrisons, Outposts, Shipyards. Deployment, PvP, and Artifacts.

docs.title: How they connect
docs.text:
• Corporations hold structures and spend Tech Points to unlock more. They use Skulls and Relics to build ships at Shipyards.
  • Structures store Artifacts (corp tech bonus; study for +1 Skill Point) and capture Relic Shrines via Garrisons.
  • Currencies fund everything: corps, upgrades, Quick Jump, and the in-game economy.

docs.title: See Also
docs.text:
• Ships — What you build at corp Shipyards and equip with items
  • World / Maps — Where structures deploy and territory is contested
  • PvP — Skulls and structure warfare

docs.title: Corporations
docs.text:
Corporations are the social backbone of The Infinite Black 2. Most game features involve working as a team: unlocking technology, capturing artifacts, harvesting relics, and fighting in the Alliance War.

Join early

There is no downside to joining a corporation and many benefits. New players should find a friendly, active corp as soon as possible. Corps can provide hunting groups, access to better ships, protection from PvP, and more.

docs.title: Leveling and skills
docs.text: Corporations earn XP from every kill, then level up and train skills just like players. A corporation's skill and technology choices apply to all ships owned by its members.

docs.title: Starting structures
docs.text:
Every corporation begins with:

  • One Planet
  • One Garrison
  • One Outpost
  • One Shipyard

These defense units are leveled up using resource deposits, which unlock more Equip Points and gear slots. Defense units may be deployed in PvP system maps to grow corporation and alliance territory.

docs.title: Unlocking more structures
docs.text: Corporation members can invest Tech Points to unlock additional defense units from the Corporation Management panel. See the Structures overview for limits (e.g. up to 4 Garrisons, 8 Outposts, 3 Shipyards).

docs.title: Corporate Defenders
docs.text: Ships owned by corp members can be summoned as Corporate Defenders to protect defense units under attack. They deploy automatically and fight under the game's AI — and recall if the owner logs in.

docs.title: Topics
docs.text: Topic Description Alliances Multiple corps in one team; shared chat, missions, and defenders. Corporate Defenders Your ships defending corp structures while you're offline. Structures Planets, Garrisons, Outposts, Shipyards — limits and deployment. Shipyards & ship building Building ships for corp members; faction choice and blueprints.

docs.title: See Also
docs.text:
• How To Play — Why joining a corp is one of your first goals
  • Ships — What you build at corp Shipyards
  • Currencies — Tech Points, Skulls, Credits
  • Maps — Where corps deploy and fight for territory

docs.title: Alliances
docs.text: Several corporations can join together as a single team, forming an alliance that captures territory and Relics in a never-ending galactic war.

docs.title: What Alliances Share
docs.text:
• Chat room — One alliance-wide chat.
  • Missions — Shared alliance missions (progress and rewards).
  • Corporate Defenders — The alliance shares one pool of defender ships; any eligible ship in the alliance can be called to any defense unit under attack.

docs.title: PvP and Friends
docs.text: All players in an alliance are friendly in PvP systems — you don't attack each other in open-world PvP. This does not apply in The Arena, where matchmaking is separate.

docs.title: Alliance Citizens
docs.text:
Alliance Citizens are players who:

  • Are Level 25+ in a corporation in the alliance, and
  • Have logged in within the last 15 days.

docs.title: Limits
docs.text:
Primary server Universe #2 Max corporations per alliance 6 6 Max Alliance Citizens (total) 180 100

Corporations cannot invite new players once the alliance citizen count is maxed. They can always invite players under Level 25 (they don't count until they hit 25). Players who haven't logged in for 15 days do not count toward the cap.

docs.title: Primary Alliance Citizen
docs.text: Each player has a single Primary Alliance Citizen character — their highest-level character. This is used for mechanics that depend on “one main per alliance,” e.g. capturing Security Rating 8 maps (citizen requirements).

docs.title: Management
docs.text:
• Click the STATS button on the Corp Panel to view alliance and citizen details.
  • Corporations can transfer Corp Tech Points to other corporations in the alliance. Use :ALLIANCE in chat for details.
  • Alliance Leaders (Commanders of the primary corporation) see Invite and Kick buttons on other corps' panels. Member corporations see a Leave Alliance button.

When someone joins or leaves

All players in the alliance are stunned for 30 seconds when a corp joins or leaves. Changes cannot be made while defense units are under attack.

docs.title: See Also
docs.text:
• Corporations
  • Corporate Defenders
  • Structures — Deploying in PvP maps
  • Relics — What alliances fight for at shrines

docs.title: Corporate Defender Ships
docs.text: Ships owned by members of a corporation can be summoned while the player is offline to help protect defense units under attack. These Corporate Defenders are deployed automatically and fight under the game's AI. If the ship's owner logs in, their defender ships recall.

docs.title: Benefits
docs.text:
• No penalty for dying — Corp Defenders killed during an attack do not lose durability or suffer other penalties.
  • Shared pool — Alliances share one pool of Corp Defenders. Any eligible ship in the alliance can be called to fight at any defense unit in the alliance.
  • Auto deployment — The strongest available defenders deploy first, with a mix of small and large units.

docs.title: Eligibility
docs.text:
A ship can be used as a Corporate Defender only if it meets all of:

Requirement Value Level 10 or higher Weapon Must have a weapon equipped Gear Score 1,000 or higher

Hardcore ships

Hardcore ships are never used as Corp Defenders.

docs.title: See Also
docs.text:
• Corporations
  • Alliances
  • Structures — What defenders protect
  • Ships

docs.title: Currencies
docs.text: The Infinite Black 2 uses several currencies and key resources. Only Credits and Skulls are tradable between players; the rest are bound to your account.

docs.title: Primary Currencies
docs.text: Currency Tradable? Summary Credits Yes Standard economy currency. Trading, raffles, converting to Tech Points. Skulls Yes PvP currency. Ship crafting, Elite Ranks, ship durability repair. Tech Points No Progression and utility. Item upgrades, corps, bank slots, Quick Jump, store. Star Shards No Premium currency. Cosmetics only (skins, trails, avatars).

docs.title: Crafting & Territory Resources
docs.text:
Resource Tradable? Summary Relics Yes Rare ship-crafting component. From Alliance Wars (shrines), Arena, level rewards, loot.

Market note

The exchange rate between Credits and Skulls fluctuates with player activity (often around 700–800 Credits per Skull). See the Auction House and in-game market for current rates.

docs.title: See Also
docs.text:
• Corporations — Tech Points for structures; Skulls and Relics for ship building
  • Ships — What you spend Skulls and Relics on
  • Getting Started — How to get Skulls, Tech Points, and Credits

docs.title: Credits
docs.text: Credits are the primary standard currency in The Infinite Black 2. They are the lifeblood of the player economy and are fully tradable between players.

docs.title: How to Obtain
docs.text:
Credits are generated through commerce and recycling:

  • Auction House — Sell items, resources, or equipment to other players.
  • Scrapping — Break down "Junk" items or scrap piles of crafted resources.
  • Trading — Direct trades with other players (including Skulls for Credits).

docs.title: Uses
docs.text:
Use Description Auction House Buy items, ships, and gear listed by other players. Raffles Buy tickets for unique ship raffles. Tech Point conversion Convert Credits into Tech Points to fuel progression.

Conversion rate

1,000 Credits → 1 Tech Point (at any time)

docs.title: See Also
docs.text:
• Tech Points — What Credits convert into
  • Skulls — The other tradable currency; often exchanged for Credits
  • Items — What you buy and sell on the Auction House

docs.title: Relics
docs.text:
Relics are a rare ship crafting component used to build Assassin, Hades, Carrier, and Emperor-class ships. Each alien faction has its own relic type for building that faction’s ships at Corporation Shipyards.

Relics are tradable like other resources — they can be sold, traded, or used yourself.

docs.title: How to Obtain
docs.text: Source Notes Alliance Wars Main source. Corps capture Relic Shrines with Garrisons; shrines generate relics. Level rewards Every 5 levels starting at Level 15. The Arena Arena rewards can include relics. Loot Dropped by NPCs. Free Daily Gifts / Holiday Events Special events and daily rewards.

docs.title: Relic Shrines (Alliance Wars)
docs.text:
• Each corporation may control 4 Relic Shrines; max 10 shrines total per alliance.
  • Captured shrines generate one relic at 100% progress. Time per 1% progress:
Shrine size Minutes per 1% Massive 78 Huge 86 Large 95 Other 104

docs.title: Alliance Points (relic distribution)
docs.text:
Each player has an Alliance Point counter that increases with kills, PvP, defense fights, Arena, and other alliance glory. Players with the most Alliance Points get priority when alliance relic loot is distributed. When someone receives a relic, their counter resets so others get a chance.

Captain Panel → STATS to see your current Alliance Points.

docs.title: Using Relics
docs.text:
• USE a relic item to add it to your crafting bank.
  • BUILD a relic via Captain Panel → Item Crafting (same crafting panel as items).

docs.title: See Also
docs.text:
• Ship Crafting — What relics are used for
  • Skulls — The other key ship-crafting currency
  • Corporations — Shipyards and shrine capture
  • Alliances — Shared relic generation and Alliance Points

docs.title: Skulls
docs.text: Skulls are a currency and crafting resource awarded to Captains only from Player-vs-Player (PvP) activity. They are tradable and used throughout the game for high-end progression.

docs.title: The Arena (best place to earn Skulls)
docs.text:
The best place to earn Skulls is The Arena: a controlled PvP environment with balanced teams and no Artifacts or Corporation Skills. Rounds run every few hours; open to any captain.

  • Minimum: One ship with Gear Score of 1,000 and no free starting gear. Some arenas require more than one ship.
  • Winning: The team with the most kills wins. High kill counts can give bonus rewards even if your team loses.
  • No durability loss on death in The Arena; gear loses only 1% durability, and only half the time.

Access via Captain Panel → ARENA when registration is open. Arena starts every few hours at the top of the hour.

docs.title: Open-world PvP and structure warfare
docs.text:
• Open-world PvP — Destroying enemy player ships in non-safe sectors.
  • Structure warfare — Bonus Skulls are awarded for defending or attacking non-NPC defense units. Join a Corporation and get involved in the Alliance Wars to earn more.

docs.title: Uses
docs.text: Use Description Ship crafting Required (with Relics) to build advanced ship blueprints at corp Shipyards. Elite Ranks Spent on the Unit Inspect Panel to upgrade ships and defense structures. Ship durability repair Use the REPAIR button on the ship inspection panel to restore durability (consumes Skulls).

docs.title: Ship Elite Rank costs (Skulls)
docs.text:
Rank Cost 1 100 2 500 3 1,000 4 2,000 5 3,000

Defense unit Elite Rank costs are 5× the ship costs.

docs.title: Market Value
docs.text: Skulls are hard to farm but needed for crafting and Elite Ranks, so they command a high price. Typical range: ~700–800 Credits per Skull (varies with the Auction House). They can be traded for wealth or consumed for progression.

docs.title: See Also
docs.text:
• The Arena
  • Corporations — Structure warfare and Alliance Wars
  • Elite Ranks
  • Relics — The other key ship-crafting resource
  • Credits — Converting Skulls to Credits (or vice versa)

docs.title: Star Shards
docs.text:
Star Shards are the premium cosmetic currency. They are used only for visual customization and do not affect gameplay stats.

Tradability: Star Shards are bound to your account.

docs.title: How to Obtain
docs.text: Source Details TIB Market (exchange) Convert Tech Points into Star Shards. 1,000 Tech Points → 2,000 Star Shards (once per day). Gameplay Earned from Outpost mission chains and defeating the final boss at the end of the chain. Store Purchasable directly for real money in the cash shop.

docs.title: Uses
docs.text: • Cosmetics — Purchase visual upgrades from the TIB Market: ship skins, engine trails, avatars, and similar items.

docs.title: See Also
docs.text:
• Tech Points — Convert into Star Shards
  • Currencies overview

docs.title: Tech Points
docs.text:
Tech Points are the main utility and progression currency. They are used for corps, item upgrades, bank space, travel, and more. You earn thousands over your career and can convert 1,000 Credits into 1 Tech Point at any time.

Tradability: Tech Points are bound — they cannot be traded between players.

docs.title: How to Obtain
docs.text:
• Conversion — 1,000 Credits = 1 Tech Point (any time).
  • Gameplay — Rewards from Missions, outpost missions, and achievements.
  • Store — Purchasable at Spellbook.com to support the game. Purchases also grant Reward Points — open Captain Panel → REWARDS for bonus gifts (Party Boxes, skins, etc.).

Oblivion Server

Tech Point orders deliver to both the Primary Server and Oblivion Server if you have a character on each. There is no link between servers and nothing transfers between them.

docs.title: Uses: Equipment & Items
docs.text:
• Item upgrades — Rank items up or down; upgrade rarity (e.g. Rare → Ultra-Rare) via the item inspect panel.
  • Research — Buy research time for technologies in the captain research menu.

docs.title: Uses: Player Convenience
docs.text:
• Bank & garage — Unlock additional Item Bank and Ship Garage slots.
  • Quick Jump — Spend Tech Points to Quick Jump to discovered locations (e.g. alliance structures, human jump gates). Cost is 1 Tech Point per jump regardless of how many ships move.

docs.title: Uses: Corporations
docs.text:
• Structures — Unlock new defense units and pay to deploy them (Corporation Management panel).
  • Member slots — Buy additional corp member slots.
  • Corp bank — Purchase extra corp bank slots for shared storage.
  • Creating a corporation — Tech Points are required to found a corp.

New player strategy

Don’t spend Tech Points on item rarity upgrades early. You earn a lot from early achievements; that flow slows later. Save them for items you’ll use long term. Your corporation can help you decide.

docs.title: See Also
docs.text:
• Credits — Converting to Tech Points
  • Corporations — Corp uses of Tech Points
  • Structures — Deployment and unlocks

docs.title: Structures Overview
docs.text:
Structures (defense units) form the backbone of territory control and economy in The Infinite Black 2. Any corporation that wants to survive must upgrade and maintain them — they build ships, protect artifacts, and spread a sphere of influence that helps members and hurts intruders.

Captains earn bonus Skulls for both defending and attacking non-NPC structures. Participation in structure warfare is one of the best ways to earn Skulls.

Gear Score requirement

Defense units must have 3,000+ Gear Score or be recalled! Equip them properly or they will be forced back.

docs.title: Corporation Limits
docs.text:
Every corporation starts with one of each type and can unlock more with Tech Points (Corporation Management panel).

Structure Start Max Notes Planets 1 1 Central hub; system-wide tech bonus; respawn option. Garrisons 1 4 Garrison Strike; only structure that can capture Relic Shrines. Outposts 1 8 Territory growth; movement/resist bonus for corp in range. Shipyards 1 3 Build ships for corp members; one faction per shipyard.

docs.title: How Defense Units Fight
docs.text:
• Firepower — Designed as 10–15 ships’ worth. Most stats are ×10 in attack calculations — one good item on a defense is like one good item on ~15 ships.
  • Weapons & drones — Attack faster than their listed speed. Slower weapons get a bigger bonus; equipping very slow weapons is highly advantageous.
  • Targeting — Defenses ignore ship size targeting limits and target nearly instantly.
  • Stat multipliers — All defense units: +Splash Chance ×10, Battery Capacity ×10, Battery Recharge ×4. No 10% auxiliary item penalty like ships. Weapons and fighter drones attack ×6 faster than normal.
  • Leveling — Level up defense units with resources from their inspect menu.

docs.title: Defense Shields (PvP)
docs.text:
When any defense unit is attacked:

  • 90-second immunity — The structure (and all ships in the sector) get a 90-second shield so defenders can organize. All ships in sector are immune to PvP during this period, including attackers.
  • 1-hour shield — After enough attackers die, a 1-hour protection shield is raised to give defenders a break.
  • :ALLIANCE SHIELD — Alliance leaders can type this in chat to raise a 4-hour shield once per day.

docs.title: Quick Jump & Tactics
docs.text:
• Quick Jump — You can Quick Jump to any structure under attack except Outposts. Cost: 1 Tech Point per jump.
  • Blocking Quick Jump — Engage an enemy defense unit to prevent defenders from Quick Jumping to it.

docs.title: Loot & Drops
docs.text:
• NPC defenses — Drop high-quality items and rare crafting components.
  • All defenses — Drop hundreds or thousands of resources when destroyed.
  • Non-NPC defenses — Players earn Skulls for killing them.

docs.title: PvE Deployment
docs.text: Defenses can be deployed in human-controlled PvE maps but recall automatically after 15 days. See Deployment for full rules.

docs.text:

Garrison Strike (area attack); ×30 Hull/Shield; capture Relic Shrines. Outposts Up to 8. Territory growth every 6h; ×12 Hull/Shield; bonuses for corp in territory. Shipyards Up to 3. Build ships; unlock blueprints; ×12 Hull/Shield.

Corporations store Artifacts at planets and garrisons for tech bonuses; any player can study an artifact for +1 Skill Point.

docs.title: Artifacts
docs.text: Artifacts are mysterious alien objects scattered across the universe in The Infinite Black 2. There are over 50 of them. Corporations capture and store them at planets and garrisons to gain technology benefits. Any player can study an artifact to permanently gain +1 Skill Point.

docs.title: Corporation Control and Tech Bonus
docs.text:
When a corporation controls an artifact (by having it stored at one of their planets or garrisons):

  • All members of that corporation receive the artifact’s technology bonus.
  • This applies regardless of the member’s Skill Tree investment or unlocked tech research — the bonus is global for the corp while they hold the artifact.
  • If the corporation loses control of the artifact (e.g. it is captured or the structure is destroyed), the tech bonus is lost for that corp. The bonus is only active while they control it.

So capturing and holding artifacts is a major goal for corps that want to boost their entire membership.

docs.title: Studying Artifacts (Skill Points)
docs.text:
Any player can STUDY an artifact. Studying is a one-time, permanent action:

  • Studying an artifact permanently awards +1 Skill Point to that captain.
  • This is a long-term goal: many players seek out artifacts over the course of the game to collect every possible bonus skill point.

docs.title: Who Can Study?
docs.text:
• Uncaptured artifacts — Any player can study them.
  • Corporation-captured artifacts — Only alliance members of the corporation that holds the artifact can study it. This is both a perk for joining that corp/alliance and an incentive for outsiders to attack and liberate artifacts so they can study them too.

Once a player has studied an artifact, the +1 Skill Point is kept forever — even if the corp later loses the artifact. Only the corp tech bonus is tied to control; the personal skill bonus is permanent.

docs.title: Structure Deployment
docs.text: Deploying Corporation structures is a strategic action that allows you to claim territory and set up forward operating bases.

docs.title: Deployment Costs & Mechanics
docs.text:
• Cost: 15 Tech Points per deployment.
  • Duration: Structures are permanent until recalled or destroyed (see PvE Exceptions below).
  • Movement: Structures are static once deployed. To move them, they must be recalled and re-deployed.

docs.title: Recall Process
docs.text:
Recalling a structure returns it to the Corporation inventory. Recalls are immediately stopped if a structure is combat flagged in an engagement.

  • Timer: Recalling takes exactly 3 minutes.
    • Note: This timer may fluctuate slightly (by a few seconds) depending on server health/tick rate.

docs.title: Restrictions & Blocking
docs.text: You cannot deploy a structure just anywhere. The following conditions must be met:

docs.title: 1. Sector Exclusivity
docs.text: Only one structure of each type can exist per sector. (e.g., You cannot place a Garrison in a sector that already has a Garrison).

docs.title: 2. Proximity Blocking
docs.text:
Deployment is blocked if Enemy Entities are present in the current sector or any connected sector (1-sector radius).

  • Blocking Entities: Enemy Structures (Player or NPC) and Enemy Player Ships.
  • Non-Blocking Entities: NPC Ships.

docs.title: 3. Combat Flag
docs.text: You cannot deploy structures while your active ship has a Combat Flag. * Workaround: You may select a different, unflagged ship to initiate the deployment.

docs.title: PvE Map Specifics
docs.text:
In PvE maps, to prevent clutter and stagnation, specific limits apply:

  • Map Capacity: There is a limit of 7 Player-Owned Structures per map.
  • Auto-Recall: Structures in PvE maps will automatically recall after 15 Days.

docs.title: Garrisons
docs.text: Garrisons are powerful defensive structures. Each corporation can have up to 4 Garrisons. They provide a Garrison Strike area attack and are the only structure that can capture Relic Shrines.

docs.title: Combat & Stats
docs.text: Feature Details Garrison Strike Area attack similar to Nova explosions. Damage is based on the Garrison’s level and Max Equip Points. Hull/Shield +Max Hull and +Max Shield stats are multiplied by ×30. Relic Shrines Relic Shrines can only be captured by placing a Garrison on them. Corps deploy Garrisons on shrines to harvest Relics for their alliance.

docs.title: Human Garrisons (PvE)
docs.text:
In PvE maps, the Human faction has Garrisons to aid travel:

  • Location: Always at Jump Gates.
  • Quick Jump: You can Quick Jump to these Garrisons if you’ve discovered them.

docs.title: Elite Ranks
docs.text: Higher-tier Garrisons need Skulls for Elite versions and offer much better durability and firepower. Defense unit Elite Rank costs are 5× ship costs (see Skulls).

docs.title: Jump Gates
docs.text: Jump Gates are static, neutral structures that connect solar systems. You use them to move between maps — you cannot cross a map edge without a Jump Gate.

docs.title: Ownership and Behavior
docs.text:
• Ownership: Jump Gates are not owned by any player or NPC.
  • Permanent: They exist as fixed points linking specific systems.
  • Combat: Jump Gates cannot be attacked or destroyed.

docs.title: Safety (PvP)
docs.text:
In PvP maps, you are relatively safe at Jump Gates between systems — but only if you are not flagged in combat. If you are in combat, you can still be attacked at the gate.

Never 100% safe in PvP

In PvP space you are never fully safe; gates only provide relative safety when not in combat.

docs.title: Quick Jump
docs.text: From the hamburger menu you can Quick Jump to any discovered human-faction Jump Gate (or to alliance defense units). Cost: 1 Tech Point per jump. Human Garrisons are located at Jump Gates in PvE maps and can be Quick Jump targets once discovered.

docs.text: Outposts expand territory and support corp members in the area. Each corporation can have up to 8 Outposts.

Corp members in territory Movement and resist bonuses. Enemies in territory Slower and less protected. Hull/Shield +Max Hull and +Max Shield stats are multiplied by ×12.

Quick Jump

You cannot Quick Jump to Outposts (including when they’re under attack). You can Quick Jump to Planets, Garrisons, and Shipyards.

Sacred Relic Shrine If a planet is deployed on a Sacred Relic Shrine, its technology bonus applies to the entire alliance throughout the entire game.

docs.text: This section covers core systems that shape how you play: missions, technology, skills, activities (PvP, PvE, Arena, Invasions), and events.

docs.title: Core Systems
docs.text:
• Missions — Personal, corp, and alliance missions.
  • Technology — 250+ techs from artifacts, corps, and items.
  • Skills — Captain, ship, and corporation skill trees (they stack).

docs.text:

  • The Arena — Structured PvP and Skull rewards.
  • Player vs Environment (PvE) — PvE content.

docs.title: Missions
docs.text: Each captain can have up to three personal missions at a time. In addition, every Corporation has a shared Corp Mission and every Alliance has an Alliance Mission. Everyone in the game also works together on one Universal Mission.

docs.title: Mission Limits & Deletion
docs.text:
• You can delete up to 3 missions per day to get new ones (resets at 00:00 UTC with daily reset).
  • Corp missions are progressed by all corp members.
  • Alliance missions are progressed by all alliance members.
  • You must participate in shared missions to get a reward.
  • Leaving your corp resets your shared mission participation (you lose progress toward corp/alliance mission rewards).

Corporations can cancel their corp or alliance missions using the :CORP and :ALLIANCE chat commands.

Kill NPC Defense Units Destroy NPC structures. Kill Players Only kills outside The Arena count, and only when a Skull is earned. 1 point per kill per mission max. Harvest Resources Gather from asteroids and nodes. Explore Solar Systems Visit and explore systems on the Starmap.

docs.title: Important Rules
docs.text:

docs.title: Skills
docs.text:
Captains, Ships, Corporations, and defense structures each have a Skill Tree. Points invested give permanent stat improvements — and all of these stack (captain + corp + ship).

New skill points come from leveling and from studying Artifacts (captured at corp planets and garrisons). Skills can be invested up to 10 points per stat, with reduced benefit above 5 (so spreading points is often wise).

docs.title: Spaceball
docs.text:
Availability

Spaceball may not be available in some countries or on some app platforms.

Spaceball is a simulated game of chance that uses in-game currency (Credits or Tech Points), not real money. It is simple to learn and easy to play.

Open CHAT and select the SPACEBALL tab to begin.

docs.title: Basics
docs.text:
• Table — There are 38 numbers: 1 through 36, plus 0 and 00.
  • Colors — Numbers 1–36 alternate RED or BLACK. 0 and 00 are GREEN.
  • Roll — The Spaceball rolls every minute to select a number.
  • Bets — You can place bets any time before the roll. Bets continue even if you close the chat window.

docs.title: Placing Bets
docs.text:
1. Click a number or betting field on the table.
  2. Choose how many Credits or Tech Points to bet.
  3. Winning bets — Payout is given immediately on the roll; your bet is returned with the payout.
  4. Losing bets — The bet is removed from the table.
  5. You can click a bet at any time to take it back.

Repeat Bet — In the bet dialog you can set a "Repeat Bet" count. If the bet loses, the same bet is re-placed automatically (even if you close the chat window).

docs.title: Bet Types
docs.text:
• Straight-Up Bet — Bet on a single number. Best payout (35 to 1) but riskiest.
  • Dozen bets — 1st Dozen (1–12), 2nd Dozen (13–24), 3rd Dozen (25–36): 2 to 1.
  • RED or BLACK — 1 to 1. Good for beginners.
  • EVEN or ODD — 1 to 1.
  • LOW (1–18) or HIGH (19–36) — 1 to 1.

RED/BLACK and EVEN/ODD are safer and best for beginners.

docs.text: Bet Payout Straight-Up (single number) 35 to 1 1st Dozen (1–12) 2 to 1 2nd Dozen (13–24) 2 to 1 3rd Dozen (25–36) 2 to 1 RED or BLACK 1 to 1 EVEN or ODD 1 to 1 1 to 18 (LOW) 1 to 1 19 to 36 (HIGH) 1 to 1

• STATS — Roll history, streaks, and other data.
  • MY LOG — Your personal bets and wins.
  • CONFIG — Mute chat or sounds.

docs.title: Responsible Play
docs.text:
Only gamble what you don’t mind losing.

Games are supposed to be fun. Anyone can develop a gambling problem. If you find yourself upset or not having fun, stop playing. Nobody ever lost by walking away.

docs.text:
There are over 250 technologies in TIB2 that affect combat, movement, crafting, and more. They come from Artifacts, corporation research, special items, and alien ships.

  • Ranked tech (e.g. Improved Hulls) does not stack with lower ranks.
  • Non-ranked tech (e.g. Analysis, Targeting) stacks with other similar benefits.

docs.title: Deflector Technology
docs.text:
Deflector gives a chance to negate all incoming damage and return it to the attacker. The negated amount is 100% (not random). The deflect roll happens after Hit/Evasion and Critical, in the final damage step. Deflector can trigger on any damage (weapons, drones, splash, battle ram).

Deflected damage is treated as an attack: it benefits from the defender's stats such as Outgoing Damage Bonus, Shield Pierce, etc.

Advanced Hacking III can disable a target's Special Item abilities, including Deflector.

docs.title: Drain Ability
docs.text: With 10+ Drain Chance a ship can use the Drain hotbar action. No battery cost to activate. Drain steals some of the target's shields and battery, making weapons and other abilities harder or impossible to use.

docs.title: How It Works (No Dice Roll)
docs.text:
• Drain Chance — Increases amount taken.
  • Drain Resist — Reduces amount. 1 point Drain Resist ≈ 2 points Drain Chance (1% for NPCs). ~20 Resist for a chance to fully resist vs +10 Drain Chance. Below 3 Battery damage: 50% resist. Below 1: always resisted.
  • Evasion (players): 5 Evasion = 1 Drain Resist.
  • Hit Chance (players): 5 Hit Chance = 1 Drain Chance.

docs.title: Base Amount
docs.text: 5 Battery + 2 (Advanced Draining) + 4 (Advanced Draining II). Each Drain Chance +1% amount; each Drain Resist −2% (or −1% NPCs).

docs.title: Reverse Drain
docs.text: Reverse Drain — 50% chance to reflect the Drain at the attacker using the target's Drain Chance (even if <10).

docs.title: Grapple Ability
docs.text: With 10+ Grapple Chance a ship can use the Grapple hotbar action. It consumes 25% battery. Grappled targets lose 25 Evasion and cannot move.

docs.title: How It Works (No Dice Roll)
docs.text:
• Grapple Chance — Increases duration of the effect.
  • Grapple Resist — Reduces duration. 1 point Grapple Resist ≈ 2 points Grapple Chance (or 1% for NPCs). ~25 Resist gives a chance to fully resist vs +10 Grapple Chance. Below 2.5 s duration: 50% resist. Below 1 s: always resisted.
  • Evasion (players): 5 Evasion = 1 Grapple Resist.
  • Hit Chance (players): 5 Hit Chance = 1 Grapple Chance.

docs.title: Base Duration
docs.text:
• Base: 4 s + 1 s (Advanced Grappling) + 2 s (Advanced Grappling II).
  • Each point of Grapple Chance adds 1% duration. Each point of Grapple Resist reduces duration by 2% (1% for NPCs).

docs.title: Reverse and Advanced
docs.text:
• Reverse Grappling — 50% chance to reflect the Grapple back at the attacker, using the target's Grapple Chance (even if <10).
  • Advanced Grappling III — Grappler can drag the target to another sector when moving. From the Grappling Hook special item and Elite Rank 3+ Cruiser.

docs.text:
With 10+ Hack Chance a ship can use the Hack hotbar action. It consumes 25% battery. Hacked targets:

  • Cannot use any hotbar ability except Repair
  • Battery does not regenerate
  • Special movement (engines, Space Lanes) does not work

docs.title: How It Works (No Dice Roll)
docs.text:

  • Hack Resist — Reduces duration. 1 point Hack Resist ≈ 2 points Hack Chance (1% for NPCs). ~25 Resist for a chance to fully resist vs +10 Hack Chance. Below 2.5 s: 50% resist. Below 1 s: always resisted.
  • Evasion (players): 5 Evasion = 1 Hack Resist.
  • Hit Chance (players): 5 Hit Chance = 1 Hack Chance.

  • Advanced Hacking III — Disables target's Special Item abilities (e.g. Nova, Deflector). Purges the Technician Repair-Over-Time immunity and applies a hack.

docs.title: Junker Technology
docs.text:
Junker can trigger a hull repair to the attacker whenever they deal damage (including drones, splash, battle ram). The attacker is repaired for 33% to 100% of the total hull damage dealt. It does not trigger if total damage is less than 30.

Junker does not benefit from other tech (e.g. Technician) or the +Hull Repair stat.

docs.title: Small Strike Team Bonus
docs.text:
When a fleet of 4 or more ships has at least 33% Small or Medium ships, the fleet gets the Small Strike Team bonus:

  • +5% Outgoing Damage for the entire fleet
  • +5 to all resists for the entire fleet

The bonus applies to all ships in the fleet, not only the small/medium ones. It encourages mixed fleet composition and squad tactics instead of stacking only large ships.

docs.title: Taunt (Tank)
docs.text:
The Tank Special item gains Taunt at Ultra-Rare rarity and above: it forces damaged enemies to attack the tank. The target change happens automatically on any HIT or CRITICAL from the tank (not on SPLASH or other damage types; it can splash during some daily events). Duration depends on the Tank item's rarity and quality.

The forced target change also triggers a new target lock cooldown for the victim, as with any target change.

docs.title: Counter
docs.text: Technician technology can remove Taunt and apply a Repair-Over-Time effect that protects the victim from negative effects for 21 seconds.

docs.title: Ranks
docs.text:

Target cannot be grappled, hacked, or taunted during ROT; one of the strongest counter-strategies. First pulse removes existing negative effects.

Repair drones with Technician can remove negative effects but cannot splash or apply repair-over-time.

When you join a Corporation you also join their alliance. In PvP maps you're on a team with everyone in that alliance. Friendly ships share vision, can follow or repair each other, and attack enemies to split XP and loot.

docs.text:
• ~10% more XP and ~20% more loot when hunting in PvP maps (vs safe space).
  • Pity loot progresses faster in dangerous areas.
  • Skulls — from killing players and from defending or attacking non-NPC defense units. Structure warfare is one of the best ways to earn Skulls.
  • Relics — Most PvP maps have a Shrine. Corps place a Garrison on the shrine to capture the map and generate Relics for the alliance.

docs.text:
• At your corp's defense units — You're relatively safe until that structure comes under attack.
  • At Jump Gates — Safe only if you're not flagged in combat.

You are never 100% safe in PvP maps. Even at your own structures, an attack can start at any time.

docs.title: This game is hard — How do I get better?
docs.text:
Combat is balanced around multiple ships. Playing with a team and deploying additional ships is critical to success!

  1. Explore 100% of the Sol Star System to earn your first ship.
  2. Click "Deploy 2nd Ship" to grow your fleet.
  3. Join a Corporation — they provide Technology, Skills, and group protection.

docs.title: What are Equip Points and how do I get more?
docs.text:
Equip Points represent how much space your ship has for mounting weapons, armor, storage, etc. Larger ships have more Equip Point capacity.

See Equip Points for details.

docs.title: What chat commands can I use?
docs.text: Several key features use chat commands (e.g. item auction history, corporation transaction logs). Type :HELP into chat for the full list.

docs.text: Drones are a type of equipment. See the Items section for details on Fighter, Harvester, and Repair drones.

docs.title: What skills should I get first?
docs.text:
• New players: +XP% Bonus helps you level quickly. Evasion is the best stat for survivability.
  • Talk to your corporation for their recommendations.
  • Remember: Corporation, Captain, and Ship Skills all stack!

docs.title: How do I get more Ship XP, Player XP, or Corp XP?
docs.text: Technology, Skills, and Items all stack to give your ships a +XP% Bonus. When you kill an NPC you gain XP based on your ship's level vs the target's level. A share of that goes to your player, and a share to your corporation — so boosting ship XP boosts all three.

docs.title: What is Ship Durability?
docs.text: When ships are destroyed they can lose a small amount of durability. This reduces certain stats (Resource Capacity, Hull, Shields, Resists). Repair ship durability with Skulls using the REPAIR button on the ship inspection panel.

docs.title: How do I get Skulls?
docs.text: Skulls are earned only from Player vs Player Combat. See the Skulls article for details and The Arena as the main way to earn them.

docs.title: What is Item Durability?
docs.text: Equipment can take damage when your ship dies. This doesn't change the item's stat bonuses, but an item at 0% Durability cannot be equipped until repaired. Repair via the item → Upgrade → Repair.

docs.title: What ship should I build first?
docs.text:
• Scrapping junk uncommon and basic gear for resources is the fastest way to build up for another ship.
  • Het and Precursor faction Cruisers are solid choices to get started in The Arena and PvP. You'll need to join a corporation with the correct faction shipyard.

docs.title: Why do my ship stats seem lower than they should be?
docs.text: See Stat Bonus Diminishing Returns. Stats use diminishing returns so stacking one stat gives less benefit the more you have.

docs.title: Stat Bonus Diminishing Returns
docs.text:
Diminishing returns in The Infinite Black 2 means that the more you stack a single stat, the less each extra point helps. This keeps balance (e.g. no infinite evasion) and lets newer players compete with less maxed gear. The concept applies to many stats: once you have more than a certain amount, additional gear that adds the same stat is slightly less effective. Your ship’s displayed stats already reflect the diminished value.

Example: Outgoing Damage. Once you have more than +5% Outgoing Damage, any extra Outgoing Damage from gear is slightly less effective. So if all your items give +6% Outgoing Damage, your ship might show about +5.8% instead of 6%.

docs.title: Resist Stat Table
docs.text:
For resist-type stats (e.g. resist damage), the total from gear is converted to an actual value used in combat as follows:

TOTAL Resist Stat ACTUAL Resist Stat 05 05.00 10 10.00 15 15.00 20 20.00 25 25.00 30 28.85 35 32.41 40 35.71 45 38.79 50 41.67 55 44.35 60 46.88 65 49.24 70 51.47 75 53.57 80 55.56 85 57.43 90 59.21

So stacking 90 total resist gives an actual 59.21; the higher you go, the more each point is scaled down.

docs.title: Chance Stat Table
docs.text:
For chance-type stats (e.g. critical chance, splash chance), the total from gear is converted to an actual value as follows:

TOTAL Chance Stat ACTUAL Chance Stat 05 05.00 10 10.00 15 15.00 20 18.85 25 22.41 30 25.71 35 28.79 40 31.67 45 34.35 50 36.88 55 39.24 60 41.47 65 43.57 70 45.56 75 47.43 80 49.21 85 50.90 90 52.50

So stacking 90 total chance gives an actual 52.50. As with resists, going past 20–25 shows clear diminishing returns.

docs.title: Why It Matters
docs.text:
• Build diversity — Maximizing one stat has a ceiling; mixing stats and item types is encouraged.
  • Catch-up — Newer players can close the gap with less perfect gear because heavy stacking is less efficient.
  • Display — The ship inspect panel shows the actual (diminished) values, not the raw sum from items.

docs.title: Gravity Drives
docs.text: Gravity Drives are a crafted engine type with a unique "Instant Jump" ability. They give each move a chance to be free — the ship arrives in the next sector with no movement cooldown. They also negate movement penalties such as those from the Interdictor Carrier.

docs.title: What Gravity Drives Do
docs.text:
1. Instant Jump chance — On each sector move, there is a chance the jump is instant: no movement cooldown in the destination sector. This makes travel faster and more unpredictable for enemies.
  2. Negate Interdictor — Interdictor Carriers slow enemy movement and increase targeting time in their sector. Gravity Drive negates these penalties for the wearer, so ships with Gravity Drives can move and fight more normally in Interdictor-affected space.
  3. Fleet following — When a ship with a Gravity Drive is leading a fleet, any following ship that also has a Gravity Drive equipped will trigger its own instant moves. So Gravity Drive fleets can move together and all benefit from instant jumps when they roll.

docs.title: Leadership (Carriers) and Gravity Drives
docs.text:
Ships with the Leadership ability (e.g. Carriers) use special rules when leading a fleet:

  • They can quick-jump every ship following them with or without Gravity Drives.
  • Their quick-jump speed is slower than the "instant" Gravity Drive jump.
  • So: for the fastest fleet movement, leading with a ship that has a Gravity Drive (and followers with Gravity Drives) gives the best results; Carriers still help move the whole fleet but at a different pace.

docs.title: Item Crafting
docs.text:
Captain Panel → ITEM CRAFTING — Blueprints and resources live here. To craft an item, collect the resources for a blueprint and click the blueprint. You discover new blueprints when you Research an item instead of scrapping it.

New players

Crafting is expensive and often supported by a corporation. Generally, scrap items for Credits unless you're committed to becoming a crafter.

docs.title: Quality
docs.text:
Each craft gives crafting skill. Skill improves the quality of crafted items:

  • Quality range: 1 to 255.
  • Each point: +0.1% to the item's stats → 25.4% difference between worst and best of the same rarity.
  • Outside The Arena, loot with quality above 100 is rare. Skilled crafters produce the strongest gear after a lot of effort.

docs.title: Skill Categories
docs.text:
There are 6 item crafting skill categories:

Category Builds Scientist Engines and Special-type items. Engineer Computers, Batteries, Storage. Weapons Weapons. Armor Armor. Shields Shields. Drones Drones.

Most Engine and Special-type items enter the game only through crafting or unique events.

docs.title: Long-Term Goal
docs.text: Item crafting is meant to be a years-long goal. Few players reach Masterwork level; their items command a premium. All crafted items are tagged with the creator's name.

docs.title: Mutate Item Kit
docs.text:
Mutate Item Kits are crafted consumable items used on a single piece of equipment. Using a kit mutates that item, adding a random stat bonus. Each item can only be mutated once in its lifetime; the mutation is permanent and the bonus is always positive.

Mutate bonuses behave like and stack with Void Item bonuses.

docs.title: How Mutate Kits Work
docs.text:
1. Craft a Mutate Item Kit from your Captain Panel (Item Crafting). The kit targets a specific item type (Weapon, Armor, Shield, etc.); that type is randomly selected when the kit is crafted.
  2. Use the kit on a piece of equipment of the matching type. The kit is consumed.
  3. The target item gains a random mutation: one stat is improved by an amount determined by a rarity roll (see table below).
  4. That item may never be mutated again. If you want a different mutation on the same item, you must use a Re-Mutate Item Kit (see below).

Mutate also increases the scrap and deconstruct value of the item by 50%.

docs.title: Mutation Rarity Chances
docs.text:
When you use a Mutate Item Kit, the strength of the mutation is rolled at random:

Rarity Chance Basic 32% Uncommon 30% Rare 20% Ultra-Rare 10% Elite 5% Legendary 2% Ultimate 1%

Each tier of mutation strength is roughly equal to 0.5 Skill Points of benefit. So an Ultimate mutation is like adding about 3.5 extra Skill Points to your ship for that stat.

The stat that is improved is random — you do not choose which stat gets the bonus.

docs.title: Equip Point Mutations (Very Rare)
docs.text: There is a very rare chance that the mutation will be an Equip Point mutation, adding +1, +2, or +3 Equip Points to the item. These are especially valuable because they increase how much gear you can fit on a ship.

docs.title: Re-Mutate Item Kit
docs.text:
If you already mutated an item and want to try for a better result:

  • Re-Mutate Item Kit — Available from Reward Point Gifts (3,000 Reward Points).
  • Using it on a previously mutated item re-rolls the mutation.
  • Re-Mutate is guaranteed to improve the mutation rarity (e.g. Rare → higher tier). The stat chosen is still random.

So: first mutation = craft and use a normal Mutate Item Kit; later improvements = Re-Mutate Item Kit from Reward Points.

docs.text: Aspect Detail Source Item Crafting; kit type random at craft Use One-time per item; consumed on use Effect Random stat bonus (or rare +EP); always positive Value ~0.5 Skill Points per tier; Ultimate ≈ 3.5 Skill Points Re-roll Re-Mutate Item Kit (Reward Point Gifts, 3,000 RP) — improves rarity, random stat Other +50% scrap/deconstruct value; stacks with Void bonuses

docs.title: Pity Loot Drops
docs.text: Most item drops use the Pity Loot System: every NPC kill adds to a counter until you get a drop. For example, after 7–8 kills you're effectively "guaranteed" an Uncommon; after 33–40, a Rare; around 300 kills, Ultra-Rare, and so on. NPCs can also drop loot at any time — when that happens, your pity counter for that rarity resets.

docs.title: Risk and Reward
docs.text:
Pity counters progress faster in more dangerous areas. You won't see much progress toward Ultra-Rare until around Security Rating 3, and you need to go further for Elite, Legendary, and Ultimate drops.

Quality of loot depends on the level of what dropped it, even for pity drops. Kill higher-level NPCs for better quality gear.

docs.title: PvP and High-Security Bonuses
docs.text:
• PvP maps progress pity faster and can produce a guaranteed rare Relic crafting component.
  • Security Rating 8 maps get a 25% loot boost.
  • Security Rating 9 Homeworld raids get double pity loot.

docs.title: What Does NOT Reset Pity
docs.text:
These do not reset your pity counters:

  • Stealing items
  • Invasion boss loot
  • Killing NPC defense units
  • Party Boxes and other non-standard loot sources

docs.title: Void Items
docs.text: Void items are a rare, powerful variant of regular equipment. Each has an extra stat bonus (similar to mutated items) that grows stronger as you upgrade the item's rarity. Void gear also gains more stats from item quality, making it better than equivalent non-Void gear.

docs.title: Weapons
docs.text: Weapons are one of the nine item types in The Infinite Black 2. They are the primary source of damage for ships and defense units. Weapons, along with Armor, Shields, and Storage, have a Rank that modifies their power and Equip Point cost; you can change rank (and other stats) via the UPGRADE button on the item inspect panel.

docs.title: How Weapons Work
docs.text:
• Damage — Weapon damage is modified by stats such as Outgoing Damage Bonus, which affects all damage (weapons, drones, battle ram, etc.). See Stats for the full list.
  • Targeting — Before a weapon can fire, the ship must acquire a target lock. Ship size affects targeting speed: large ships target small ships more slowly. Targeting Speed stat modifies lock-on speed.
  • Battery — Most weapons consume battery to fire; Battery and Engine items affect capacity and recharge.
  • Defense units — Weapons (and fighter drones) on structures attack faster than their listed speed; slower weapons get a bigger bonus. Defenses also ignore size-based targeting limits and target nearly instantly.

docs.title: Weapon Slots and Fleet
docs.text: Ships have multiple weapon slots. Elite Ranks on the Striker Gunboat add more slots (e.g. Elite Rank 3 adds +1 Weapon Slot, Elite Rank 4 adds another). Equip Points limit how many high-rank weapons you can fit; see Equip Points and Stats.

docs.title: Related Item Types
docs.text:
• Fighter Drones — Behave like weapons that don’t consume battery; they ignore size disparity, so Carriers are effective vs small targets.
  • Armor / Shield — Defensive items; see Stats for Hull, Shield, and resist stats.
  • Item Crafting — One of the six crafting categories is Weapons; see Item Crafting.

docs.title: Ships
docs.text: Your fleet is the heart of The Infinite Black 2. You command multiple ships, each with its own equipment, level, and role. Combat is balanced around multiple ships — new players should explore 100% of Sol to earn a second ship and join a Corporation for ship construction and tech.

docs.title: Ship Classes
docs.text:
There are 10 ship types in TIB2:

Size Classes Small Shuttle, Frigate, Assassin Medium Cruiser, Destroyer Large Battleship, Flagship Huge Carrier, Hades Massive Emperor

Each of the 5 factions (Human, Wyrd, Het, Precursor, Pirate) has its own variant of each class — 50 different ships in total. Ship size controls movement speed, targeting speed, Equip Points, and more.

docs.title: Fleet Size Requirements
docs.text:
Your fleet must contain a mix of ship sizes to deploy more slots:

Fleet size Requirement 8 ships MEDIUM or smaller 9 ships SMALL + MEDIUM or smaller 10 ships SMALL + MEDIUM + LARGE or smaller

Smaller ships satisfy larger requirements (e.g. a MEDIUM counts as your LARGE slot). See Small Strike Team Bonus for the benefit of fielding small/medium ships.

docs.text: Players begin in a Striker Gunboat with better-than-average ability and decent gear. Striker Gunboats gain more equipment slots and Equip Points with Elite Ranks. You can own 100+ ships of any type and deploy several at once.

docs.title: Deception Module
docs.text:
The Deception Module is a ship upgrade that hides information from other players — such as equipped gear, Equip Points used, and various stats. It does not replace or conflict with Ship Mods and works on any ship. You can toggle deception on or off from the Ship Inspect panel.

Deception effects grow stronger with Elite Rank: higher rank hides more slots and item types.

docs.text: More is hidden as the ship’s Elite Rank increases. The following lists show what is hidden at or above each rank.

docs.title: Equip Points
docs.text:
Equip Points are the capacity your ship (or defense structure) has for mounting weapons, armor, shields, batteries, drones, and other equipment. Larger ships have more Equip Points.

The sum of all equipped items' costs cannot exceed the ship's maximum. Item rank and rarity affect how many points each piece uses.

Full details coming soon

See Ships and FAQ for now.

docs.title: Hardcore Ships & Defense Units
docs.text: Any ship or defense unit can be set to Hardcore (opt-in). Hardcore units gain strong bonuses but drop equipment and lose more durability on death. Corporate Defender ships are never chosen from Hardcore ships — only non-Hardcore eligible ships can be used as Corp Defenders.

docs.title: Hardcore Bonuses
docs.text:
When a ship or defense unit is Hardcore:

  • −10% Movement Cooldown — Faster sector-to-sector movement.
  • +25 Skill Points — Extra skill points to spend.
  • +3 Equip Points — Ships gain 3 more EP. Corporate defense units gain +10 Equip Points when Hardcore.
  • +5 additional Skill Points — Hardcore units can invest 5 more skill points (on top of the +25), for greater build flexibility.

docs.title: Hardcore Penalties and Rules
docs.text:
• Drop on death — When a Hardcore unit dies, it drops 1 random equipped item.
  • No free newbie gear — Hardcore units cannot equip free starter/newbie gear.
  • Durability — Hardcore units lose slightly more durability on death than non-Hardcore.

So Hardcore is high risk, high reward: better stats and EP, but death costs you an item and more durability.

docs.title: Corporate Defenders and Phoenix
docs.text:
• Corp Defenders — Corporate Defender Ships are drawn from corp/alliance members’ ships. Hardcore ships are never used as Corp Defenders; only eligible non-Hardcore ships are considered.
  • Phoenix Ship Mod — Ships with the Phoenix mod cannot go Hardcore, and Hardcore ships cannot use the Phoenix mod.

docs.title: Oblivion Server
docs.text:
On the Oblivion Server, rules are harsher:

  • Hardcore ships lose 100% durability on death and drop all equipped items.
  • Hardcore ships that get the killing shot generate pity loot at 2× the Oblivion accelerated rate, stacking with other loot bonuses (e.g. up to 10× or more during invasions).
