docs.title: Interdictor Carrier
docs.text:
The Interdictor is a Ship Mod that is crafted from your captain’s Item Crafting panel. It allows a Carrier-class ship to become an Interdictor, permanently replacing the Carrier’s Leadership bonus with a sector-wide penalty to enemies.

Gravity Drives negate the Interdictor’s movement penalties for ships that have them equipped.

docs.title: What the Interdictor Does
docs.text:
• Sector penalty — The Interdictor projects an effect in nearby sectors that:
  • Increases enemy targeting and movement times by up to 30% (strength grows with the Carrier’s Elite Rank).
  • Removes other movement benefits such as Space Lanes.
  • One per sector — Only one Interdictor can have influence in a given sector. It is assigned to the first to arrive or the most powerful Interdictor (by tech rank). Any other Interdictors that enter later (or with lower tech) suffer the penalty like every other enemy — they do not stack or share control.
  • No effect in The Arena — The Interdictor effect does not work in The Arena.

docs.title: Crafting
docs.text:
• Interdictor is crafted like the Ultimate ship mod.
  • Requires identical fragments and Relics all from the same faction.
  • The final crafted item is the same regardless of faction; only the source materials must match.

docs.title: Ship Crafting
docs.text: Corporations level up their Shipyards to unlock ship blueprints. Members build ships at the corp's shipyard; each Shipyard is dedicated to one faction (Pirate, Het, Wyrd, or Precursor). Corp leadership chooses the faction, opening advanced alien-class ships with different technology — more powerful but more expensive.

docs.title: Requirements
docs.text:
• Larger ships have more Equip Points, allowing stronger items.
  • Advanced ships require Skulls and Relics in addition to basic resources.
  • You need a corporation with the right faction shipyard to build that faction's ships.

docs.title: Ship Stat Bonus Mod
docs.text:
When you craft a ship it gains a random Ship Stat Bonus Mod. Its strength is comparable to a number of Skill Points:

  • Random roll: Between 3 and 12 Skill Points equivalent.
  • Maximum (12) is only possible during rare daily crafting events.
  • Ship Stat Modification items can drop as loot, letting you replace this crafted bonus.

docs.title: Corporation Ship Crafting Skill
docs.text: Building a ship increases your corporation's ship crafting skill for that faction (e.g. building a Wyrd Reaper increases Wyrd Ship Crafting Skill). Corporations can earn up to 1,000 ship crafting skill points per day. Higher corp ship crafting skill improves the Ship Stat Bonus Mod on newly built ships.

docs.text: There is a 1% chance a crafted ship gains +1 Equip Point; rarely +2 or +3.

docs.title: Ship Mods
docs.text:
Ship Mods are consumable items that permanently modify a ship. There are 8 of them. Once applied, the ship gains new bonuses and technologies that can be improved further through Elite Ranks. To preview how a ship would change, use the mod on a ship but cancel the final confirmation popup.

Except for Interdictor (Carrier-only), ship mods can be applied to any ship. Although they are effectively permanent, they can be reclaimed with Tech Points from the ship’s detail panel.

Guarantees critical attacks vs injured enemies and critical repairs on injured friends. The Arena: earn a Gladiator mod and titles for every 100 victories. Phoenix Adds Rebirth and Savior technology. Converts fatal damage into a large repair and instant cloak; improves repairs on injured friends. Rebirth works in PvP and PvE with separate cooldowns. docs.title: Ship and Defense Unit Size
docs.text: Every combat entity has a size: Small, Medium, Large, Huge, or Massive. Size affects movement speed, evasion, and weapon targeting speed. See the Ships page for fleet size and captain level requirements.

docs.title: Targeting
docs.text:
Before weapons can fire, a target lock must be acquired. The greater the size difference, the longer it takes for a large ship to lock onto a small one. Big ships are meant to fight other bigs and have trouble targeting shuttles and frigates.

  • Small ships — Can't carry as much, but are much more evasive. Use small ships to target other small ships and leave big guns for big targets.
  • Defense units (Planets, Garrisons, etc.) — No targeting limit; they target nearly instantly. Very slow weapons on defenses get an attack speed bonus.
  • Fighter drones — Ignore size disparity, so Carriers are strong against small targets.

docs.text:

Size Warm-up Small 0.7 s Medium 1.0 s Large 1.3 s Huge / Massive 1.7 s

The Skip Drive Engine and Gravity Drives (crafted engine) reduce this to 0.5 s for any ship.

docs.title: The World
docs.text: The universe of The Infinite Black 2 is not a single infinite void, but a collection of distinct Solar Systems (Maps) connected by a network of Jump Gates.

docs.title: The Map Grid
docs.text: Every Solar System is a 15x15 Grid of Sectors. * Coordinates: Ranges from (0,0) in the bottom-left to (14,14) in the top-right. * Traversal: Crossing the edge of a map does not loop you around; you must use a Jump Gate to leave the system.

docs.title: Navigation
docs.text: To travel the universe, a Captain must move their fleet through individual Sectors. * Movement: Click an adjacent sector to engage engines. * Speed: Movement speed is determined by your slowest ship (or largest hull). * Safety: Some systems are patrolled by the Earth Defense Force (Safe), while others are lawless warzones (PvP). See Map Security Ratings for details.

docs.title: Factions
docs.text: The Starmap is controlled by five factions. Each has its own ship variants, homeworld, and lore. Human-controlled space is safe; the other four factions control systems where PvP is possible and where corporations fight for territory and Relics.

docs.title: Faction Lore
docs.text:
Faction Summary Full article Wyrd Spider-like species; venom, mandibles, possible telepathy; transformed the Hets. Wyrd Het Once docile, now aggressive; hive-mind pods; weaponized by Wyrd; organo-metallic. Het Precursor Ancient, robotic forms; conflict with The Oblivion; cryptic guardians. Precursor Pirates Humans who fled Earth; corporate vs pirate; clones, codes of honor. Pirates Humans Corporate and EDF; Sol and colonial space; safe PvE space. —

Each faction has a homeworld at (7, 7) in its Security 9 map — see Planets. Shipyards can specialize in one faction for ship building.

docs.title: The Het
docs.text: The Hets are a mysterious species that live in open space and move in large herds or pods (similar to Earth's cetaceans), with an average pod size of about fifty. Individual encounters are extremely rare. Their social structure is almost nonexistent — they seem to operate on a hive-mind, with a single unit acting only for the pod's well-being, with no regard for individuality.

docs.title: History
docs.text:
• Once docile — Hets used to become aggressive only when threatened, preferring to flee or resorting to organized swarm attacks if necessary. They were mainly a navigation hazard, attacking ships only when their young were endangered.
  • Wyrd virus — The Wyrd introduced a techno-organic virus to weaponize the Hets against humans. The Hets developed organo-metallic armor and bio-organic weapons.
  • Loss of control — Contrary to Wyrd expectations, the Hets resisted control and became a major threat to both Wyrd and humans. Human technology has since adapted to harvest and integrate Het organs into their ships.

docs.title: Biology and Behavior
docs.text:
• Form: Hets resemble organic long ships with flukes and tails; they are believed to travel using solar wind currents.
  • Personality: They show no signs of distinct personalities, likely due to hive-mind dominance.

docs.title: The Pirate Faction
docs.text: Pirates are humans who originated on Earth in the Sol system. Severe over-pollution and resource exploitation forced many to flee; corporations saved their loyalists and abandoned the rest, leading to the death of billions. Pirate Fleets formed from survivors in ragtag, improvised ships.

docs.title: Earth and the EDF
docs.text: The Earth Defense Force is a fascist, nationalistic human faction that remains on the planet, guarding what little is left. Their main export is a constant flow of desperate colonists, the elderly, and prisoners. They often give earthlings a small ship in exchange for permanent indentured servitude.

docs.title: Humans in Space
docs.text:
• Adaptation — Humans on other planets and stations have adapted to their environments, with visible physical and genetic differences among colonial populations. All are carbon-based, breathe oxygen, and have a nine-month gestation period; traits like hair, height, and weight vary widely.
  • Clones — Corporations have augmented their forces with vat-grown clones engineered for war (no pain or fear). It is estimated that over 70% of all living humans in the universe are warrior clones, fighting aliens and each other.

docs.title: Corporate vs Pirate Humans
docs.text:
• Corporate — Driven by greed; corporate espionage and deceit are common. There is no shared code of honor; profits go to leadership.
  • Pirate — Also pursue wealth but often abandon social bonds and follow laws or a code of honor. Codes vary by clan and are important for negotiation and trade.

Humans have been in open war with every known alien species for hundreds of years. Most believe the only alternative is extinction and that survival is what matters.

docs.title: The Precursors
docs.text: The Precursors are a profoundly ancient alien race, present in the universe for billions of years. They are known for their ostensibly robotic forms — it is unclear whether these are their real bodies or avatars. Their advanced technology includes self-destruct mechanisms that prevent capture and study, so they remain enigmatic.

docs.title: Conflict and Role
docs.text:
• The Oblivion — The Precursors are engaged in an obscure conflict with a formidable entity known as The Oblivion. The exact nature of this struggle and its implications are not well understood.
  • Communication — They communicate with other species, including humans, in a way that is urgent and often cryptic, suggesting they see themselves as guardians against greater cosmic threats. The extent and motivation of this protective stance are as mysterious as their origins.

docs.title: What Remains Unknown
docs.text: Little is known about their societal structures, culture, or ultimate goals. Their interactions with other species combine warning and oblique guidance, adding to their complex role in the setting.

docs.title: The Wyrd
docs.text: The Wyrd are an alien species that bear a resemblance to Earth's spiders: eight limbs — six as legs, two with hands and multiple fingers, allowing intricate tasks with greater precision than humans. Little is known about their social structure; most knowledge comes from injured specimens.

docs.title: Biology and Behavior
docs.text:
• Size: Captured specimens are comparable in size and weight to Earth's horses.
  • Features: Eight eyes, large venomous mandibles adapted for grinding prey.
  • Venom: A potent neurotoxin that paralyzes prey while keeping it alive for feeding or storage; they may use captured prey as live hosts for their eggs.
  • Communication: Wyrd can mimic human speech; their native communication involves complex clicks and screeches. Scientists suggest a possible telepathic component — efforts to understand their language have failed.

docs.title: Society
docs.text: All observed Wyrd have been male, leading to speculation that captured individuals are a worker or warrior caste. Other members of the species may be more dangerous, with greater size, strength, or intelligence. There is no insight into individual Wyrd personalities.

docs.title: Role in the Universe
docs.text: The Wyrd introduced a techno-organic virus to the Het in an attempt to weaponize them against humans. The Hets instead became an aggressive threat to both Wyrd and humans; humans later adapted technology to harvest and integrate Het organs into their ships.

docs.title: Maps
docs.text: The universe is made of solar systems (maps). Each map is a 15×15 grid of sectors. There are over 50 solar systems to explore, with different security levels, factions, and rewards.

docs.title: Viewing the Starmap
docs.text:
Hamburger menu (near your player button) → Starmap.

From the Starmap you can see systems, Security Ratings, and plan travel. Use Jump Gates to move between systems.

docs.title: PvE vs PvP
docs.text:
Map type Safety Shown on Starmap Human-controlled (PvE) Safe — no player attacks Typically blue Other factions (PvP) PvP possible Different coloring

You are always safe in human-controlled space. Beyond that, Corporations and Alliances battle for territory and Relics. Each of the five factions (Humans, Wyrd, Hets, Precursors, Pirates) controls systems and has a powerful homeworld that advanced corps can raid for high-value rewards.

docs.title: Quick Jump
docs.text:
From the hamburger menu you can Quick Jump to:

  • Any defense unit in your alliance
  • Any human-faction jump gate you’ve discovered

Cost: 1 Tech Point per jump (no matter how many ships move).

docs.title: Sectors
docs.text:
Each solar system (map) is a 15×15 grid of sectors. You move from sector to sector by clicking adjacent squares; you cannot wrap around the edge — use a Jump Gate to leave the system.

  • Coordinates: From (0,0) at the bottom-left to (14,14) at the top-right.
  • Contents: Enemies, asteroids, other players, and structures (e.g. corp defenses, jump gates).

docs.title: Collision (Stacking Limit)
docs.text:
Too many ships in one sector causes a Collision mechanic (damage over time) to reduce lag. Collision triggers when:

Condition Limit Total ships in the sector More than 225 Ships per alliance in the sector More than 75 Enemies attacking a defense unit More than 75 (any alliance)

See PvP for context on alliance stacking and structure defense.

docs.title: Security Rating
docs.text:
Security Rating (SR) defines how dangerous a sector of space is in The Infinite Black 2. It directly affects the strength of enemy ships, the risk of travel, and the level of preparation required to survive.

Security Ratings range from SR1 (safest) to SR9 (most dangerous).

Indicative data

The level and ship-per-sector ranges below are indicative and may be adjusted with game balance. Replace with official data when available.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
As you move farther from protected space, security decreases and threats escalate. Higher Security Ratings feature:

  • Stronger and more aggressive enemy ships

  • Higher-level equipment and builds on NPCs

  • Increased likelihood of rapid ship destruction if unprepared

Progression Warning

Entering a higher Security Rating than your ship can handle will almost always result in destruction.

docs.title: Practical Effects of Security Rating
docs.text:
Security Rating influences more than just enemy strength:

  • Travel Risk: Higher SR sectors leave little time to react to ambushes

  • Ship Loss: Destruction is common in high SR without proper defenses

  • Preparation Requirements: Shield tier, weapon optimization, and build synergy become mandatory

docs.title: Tips for Pilots
docs.text:
• Progress gradually through Security Ratings rather than skipping ahead

  • Treat each SR increase as a gear and build check

  • If enemies feel overwhelming, retreat and improve your ship before advancing

Survival Rule

If you can’t comfortably win multiple fights in a sector, you’re not ready for its Security Rating.
